div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,425] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definaitely engaged beforehand: Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monda.A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving inLondon at the very convenient hour of 4.56.p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fair is £22.9.11 Port Said to London vis Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leaves Suez for Aden and Bombay every WEdnesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

Regular Service between Italy and United States throughout the year. Excellent accommodation for all classes of passengers. div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about noon with Vienna express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and as to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 28 February, 14 March; 1, 11 & 25 April; 1, 9 & 22 May ; 6 June, 4 p.m.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Our predictions of a fl e day yesterday were falsifled. The morning opened bright and clear but the conditions soon changed, Some rain fell accompanied by hall during the day, and at 9 p.m. there was an unusually heavy downpour of hail which was of ahort duration. This morning opens cool, but raw and cloudy, with a light breeze from the W. and a rising barometer.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
OBSERVATIONS BY SURVEY DEPARTMENT
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1906

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON BOOM
div.p: It is so inspiriting to bear of any British manufacturing industry in a highly prosperous condition despite hostile foreign tariffs that patriotism shrinks from casting doubt on the continuance of the phenomenal boom in English cotton goods. This happy change from the long period when so many Lancashire mills were either closed or only running half-time began eighteen months ago, the American “corner” in the raw material haring utterly collapsed for the time being. In itself, this sodden expansion was both natural and legi¬timate ; in all parts of the world, stocks in hand had almost reached exhaustion point, owing to the prolonged limitation of supply. When, therefore, millowners were enabled, by toe heavy fall in the price of raw cotton, to increase output with good prospect of substan¬tial profit, foreign importers from Manchester hastened to replenish their stocks at the lower rates. But another effect was produced by this sudden augmentation of the external de¬mand. It stimulated the building of new factories to an unprecedented extent; a cor¬respondent of the "Morning Poet” estimates that in another six months, Lancashire will have in operation between three and four million spindles and forty-five thousand looms more than existed when the boom began. The future output will thus be increased by 10 percent., and should the foreign demand slacken, over-production will be sure to involve the inevitable penalty. But there is another menace, and, perhaps, of even more grave character. The American "corner” is scotched, not killed, and it only requires the stimulus of a short crop to ran up prices to record level, again paraysing the great Lancashire industry. There can never be any real safeguard against that standing danger until the British Cotton- Growing Association succeeds in its patriotic endeavour to render England independent of the New Orleans supply.

div.head: NILE VALLEY COMPANY
div.p: In another column we publish a report of the important meeting of the Nile Valley Company held on Monday week. At that meeting the reconstruction proposals were unanimously agreed to, the quotation harden¬ing perceptibly as soon as the news reached the market. Among the economies which are to be effected are a reduction in the managing director’s salary from £1,000 to £230 e year, with 2 1/2 percent commission on dividends, a reduction of £100 in the secretarial fees and office charges, a diminution in the fee of the consulting engineer by 250gs, and a decrease of £900 in directors’ fees. These, it may be argued, are comparatively small retrenchments, but we understand that they may be taken as indicative of a policy of financial reform which is to be pursued as assiduously in Egypt as in London. The Nile Valley is a very fair mining risk, and it is by no means unlikely that shareholders who have gone into the re¬construction will see the whole of their money back in due time.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES
div.p: It was stated a few days ago that the Empain group of Brussels had decided to taka in hand the reconstruction of this unfortunate Egyptian sugar concern. On enquiries made in Paris circles in close touch with the Empain group, I am (a correspondent of a financial contemporary says) able to state that the news is not likely to be true ; so far, not the least confirmation exists. M. Empain’s visit t> Cairo, where the affairs of the newly promoted Helio¬polis Tramway Company required hi presence, baa no doubt given rise to the rumour. On the other hard, it is more than ever certain (adds the correspondent) that Sir Ernest Cassel and his friends are actively engaged in the reconstruction scheme.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Quarantine.
Quarantine restrictions as against plague are new applied to arrivals from Bassein in Egyptian ports.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alex­andria, at 4.45 p.m. to-day.
Coptic National Council.
A Khedivial decree has been issued confirm­ing the election of twenty-tour members of the Coptic National Council at Cairo.
Cairo’s New Artesian Wells.
The official inauguration of the artesian wells at Rodel Farag will take place on March 15H.H the Khedive will probably be present at the ceremony.
Asile Rudolph,
M. Phil. D Philippides has contributed £1 and M. and Mme D. Theodorakis a similar amount to the Radolph Home, in memory of the late Hans von Tschndi.
Anglo-Egyptian Cigarette Company.

With the arrival of this company's n a-aging director, Mr. Max Prsedecki, the procuration given to Mr. Karl Lockemann daring his absence has ceased, and the signature of Mr. Przedecki will therefore alone be valid.
Concert.

A seiree musicale will be given in the hall of the Union Artisiquee Francaise on Friday next at 9 30 p.m. by Maestro F. Corbo, who comes from the Parma Conservatoire, assisted by Mile Capozzo, M. N. Naumides, and M. A. Roben.
The Doctors’ Tariff.

There will be a meeting this evening at the headquarters of the Risorgimento Society to consider the report of the committee on the conference which it had with the Alexandria Doctors Society on the subject of the new medical tariff The meeting will begin at 7 o’clock this evening.
The Pilgrims' Return.

The Ministry of the Interior has received a telegram from the Quarantine Board representative at Tor, stating that the S S. Rahmanieh arrived there yesterday with 660 Egyptian pilgrims on board on their return from the Hedjaz. They are all in good health, except three.
A Free Dispensary.

A free dispensary for sick children was opened in Boulac at a new house in Sharia Maatba el Ahlia, near the Cotton Mills, yester­day. Mothers with sick babies may bring them from 8 a.m. till 10 a.m. daily for treatment gratuitously. This dispensary has been founded by Lady Cromer and is entirely supported by voluntary contributions.
Egypt Exploration Fund.

A new publication of the Fund is about to be issued comprising the fifteenth memoir of the Archaeological Survey of Egypt. It consists of part 111 of the work on the took tombs of El Arnarna. The author is Mr. N. do G. Davies and Mr. Seymour ce Ricci contributes an appendix on Greek Graffiti. The work is illustrated by 40 plates.
Dog Regulations.

As so many people seem to ignore the actual text of i he law concerning dogs, we may state that the order relating thereto runs as follows: - "All cogs running in the streets or public places in the town of Cairo or suburbs, must be muzzled or led on a leash. In either case they most wear a collar with a metal plate bearing name and address of the owner.”
Football.

A capital game of football was witnessed at Gheziret Badrane last Friday, when the home earns and the R.E. met in their return match. The game was a very fast one and not until the final whistle blew did the tremendous excite­ment cease from reigning. In the first hail the exchanges were of an even character, and both custodians were called upon in torn. A notable feature of the match was the excellent exhibition given by the visitors’ goalkeeper and many of his saves were really brilliant. When well into the second half, Simmonds scored a beautiful goal for the home team after a pretty piece of individual play. There was no further scoring and so the game conclude in a win for the Railway Institute by l-0 after a well contested game. Mr. Trotter was referee.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

Three Sailings a-Week.

Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES
div.p: EGYPT'S PROSPERITY.
IMPORTANT ARTICLE IN "TIMES."
(Gazette's Special Service)
London, Tuesday

An important communication appears in to­day’s “Timer,” wherein the present conditions of Egypt are reviewed. The writer, after starting with the contrary view, concludes that the continuous increase in land values in Egypt is a solid basis tor the country's prosperity. One of the most investing points in the article is the reference to the great difficulty in the future, when Lord Cromer’s guidance of Egypt comes to an end, for it will be a serious matter to find a successor. The Capitulations are, it is declared, a real danger to the country and their abolition is necessary. The writer gees on to state that the ranks and decorations con­ferred by the Khedivial Government should be for recognized merit only.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service)
London, Tuesday.
There ii a very large demand for Deferred shares of the Egyptian Estates, Limited, which rose yesterday to 8 3/4, the ordinary being quoted 1 7/8.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LTD.
div.p: The subscription list for this new issue, which we announced yesterday, will be opened not to-day, the 22nd inst., as stated, but on Monday next, the 26th inst., and the two following days.
The company was registered in London on the 16th inst. and following are the names of the subscribers to the memorandum of asso­ciation with the numbers of the shares taken

div.head: THE DAIRA SANIEH CASE.
div.p: Yesterday the Second Civil Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Court gave judgment in the case brought by the villagers of Arment against the Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh. The plaintiffs claim that their village has been sold over their heads. They were non-suited

div.head: KHARTOUM LANDS
div.p: The “Sudan Times” states that the 3nd»n Government has been approached by a powerful company which proposes to fill the agricultural lands in the western part of the town and raise them to the town level, the company to be granted half the land thus reclaimed. It is said that the Government is considering the proposal favourably. But, on the other hand, this seems doubtful, as it would be cheaper for the Government to do the work unaided. A few dredgers can serve the double purpose of clearing the river to facilitate navigation and filling the land in question.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: Iris, not having recovered from the effects of her drenching, will not appear before Thursday, and last night Fedora took her place. The damages were inspected - we cannot say estimated—by Harari Pacha, M. Rocca Serra, Mr. Perry, and M. Pietri. Nothing is known of the damage done to the scenery as it was rolled up at the time of the accident and no one cares to enroll it till quite dry. Meantime it is rather curious, to say the least of it, that the Ministry of Public Works, on which the Opera House is dependent, has not' thought fit to make any communique to the Press on the subject.

div.head: JUDICIAL APPOINTMENTS
div.p: Ahmed Bey Abdeen, judge in the Native Court of Alexandria, has been appointed chief judge to the Court of Beni Souef, Upper Egypt; and Hussein Bey, a Parquet agent, judge of the 2nd class in the Native Court of Alexandria.
Many other transfers and appointments of judges have taken place, in accordance with a Khedivial edict recently issued.
Boutros Bey Youssef, judge in the Mixed Court of Mansourah, has refused to replace Mohamed Bey Naggari, judge in the Alexandria Mixed Court of First Instance who has been transferred to Cairo.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Menes arrived at Liverpool esterday afternoon.
The Messageries Maritimes S. S. Congo arrived at Marseille from Alexandria this morning.

div.head: THE FRONTIER INICIDENT.
div.p: NEGOTIAITIONS ADVANCE.
ARRIVAL OF TURKISH OFFICIERS

We are informed that two Turkish officers of high rank belonging to the General Staff of the Ottoman Army, are on their way from i Constantinople to Egypt to discuss the frontier question with the Egyptian authorities. This marks a distinctly forward step in the course of the negotiations.

div.head: NEW PENSION LAW.
div.p: The Egyptian Government is at present obtaining expert actuarial advice on the subject of a new Pension Law from Messrs. Ryan and Wyatt, whose competence as high actuarial authorities has long been recognised in Eng­land. Messis. Ryan and Wyatt have already arrived at Cairo.

div.head: GREECE AND EGYPT
div.p: Mr. A. Naoum, first dragoman of the Hellenic Legation at Constantinople, was presented by M Rikakis on Monday to Mustapha Pacha Fehmy and the other members of the Cabinet, and paid calls yesterday on Lord Cromer and the other representatives of the Powers.

div.head: BRIDGING THE NILE.
div.p: The Cleveland Bridge a> d Engineering Com­pany, of Darlington, have been commissioned to take the borings across the Blue and the White Niles at Khartonm. with a view to ascertaining the nature of the strata and the most suitable types of railway bridges to construct at these points, where the Blue and the White Niles are each 1,200 feet wide. As the boring operations have to be concluded before July next, when the Niles will be in fall flood, a party of engi­neers are leaving for Khartoum on the 23rd inst The expedition will be accompanied by Mr. W. E. Pease, of Mowden, Darlington—a direct r of the Cleveland Bridge and Engineer­ing Company—and the boring operations will be under the charge of Mr. G. C. Imbault, of Darlington, the engineer who was in charge of the erection of the railway bridge over the river Zambesi at the Victoria Falls, which was only recently completed by the Cleveland Bridge and Engineering Company.

div.head: THE WALL OF THE TIGRANES
div.p: The action brought by Mr. Georgacopoulo, owner of the New Khedivial Hotel at Cairo, against the heirs of the late Tigrane Pacha, came on for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Coart yesterday. The plaintiff was represented by Maitre Schaar and Maitre Privat appeared for the defendants. The case is based on the wail built by the Tigranes, the only purpose of which, plaintiff alleges, is to cut off the air and light from his property. Counsel f r the latter showed that the wall was an absolutely ageless construction and had only been built to fulfil a vow formulated by the late Tigrane Pacha, and that the Court should order its demolition in accordancee with the legal maxim ‘‘Malitiis hominum non eat indulgendum.”
Judgment will be delivered in a week.

div.head: TRADE IN GUM ARABIC
div.p: The exports of gum arabic from Egypt daring last year amounted to 8,838 636 kilo­grammes, of the total value of LE. At 7,133, as compared with 10,400 610 kilos and L E. 234,034 in 1904, a decline of 1,561.974 kilos

div.head: ABBASSIEH OASIS
div.p: THE PRINCE OF LAND
WHAT THE COMPANY IS DOING.

A slight decrease in the value of land at Zeitoun has been noticed since the formation of the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company. Speculators have been soared at the immense quantity of land which this company could place on sale at a low price

We do not think, however, that these appre­hensions are justifiable. In the first place, the company has no interest in selling its lands before the construction of’ the electric railways, the tran ways, the roads, etc. Second­ly. as the real cost price of these lands is rather high, it is impossible for them to sell them at a low price. In this connection it is to be noted that, albeit the price paid to the Government for the land is very small, the sum necessary to give it a market value will be enormous. There is a costly railway to be built, tramways to be laid, a supply of water and electricity to be furnished, roads to he made, pavements, public parks, etc,etc. Briefly, after spending £*00.000, as the area of the laud which is to be sold in lots amounts to two million square metres, the “immediate” price of the lands for sale comes to 40 piastres a square metre. We have said the “immediate” price because the price must be increased every year and this for some time, through losses on the working of the railway, the tram­ways, the distribution of water and electricity. It is certain that the rentals for the villas and hotels on the construction of which the company is to spend from £400 000 to £500,000 will hardly suffice to make up for these initial losses of exploitation. To all this must be added interest on £1.200,000 to £1.800.000, which, at 5 per cent., represents an annual anm 60000 to 65000

All this enumeration of charges brings ns to the conclusion that if the “immediate” cost price is 40 piastres per square metre, this price mast be increased by 8 to 3^ piastres a year to keep pace with the interest on the money expended

With the view of granting certain advant­ages to those persons who are the first to come and build on the Oasis, it is possible, and even probable, that the company will sell a hun­dred lots of 1,000 to 2,000 square metres, at the maximum, at lower than cost price, on condition only that houses are construct­ed the eon within a year ; bat, as we said above, it is not these hundred lots of land to be sold cheap which is likely to have an influence on the value of land at Zeitoun or Matarieh.

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY
div.p: A Syrian trader who has recently arrived in Egypt from Palestine informed one of our representatives yesterday that a considerable movement of troops, mainly infantry of the Nisam (first line) from Ma’an to Qala’st Medawara, had recently taken place. Five thousand men are now engaged on railway work near Medawara, where water abounds and where there is a certain amount of cultivation. These troops were all armed with the Martini.

Preliminary surveys of the Ma’an-Akaba route having proved that a line between these points would be very costly and that the want of water would be a serious impediment to construction, it was finally decided to consider the question of a line between Qala’at Medawara over the Hisma plateau. A pre­liminary survey of the line by a party com j posed of an Italian, two Turkish engineers, and a Pole showed that no great natural difficulties existed, and in September last three Germans, who were said to have come from Akaba, arrived at Damascus from Me dawara. having made a farther survey of the route. The construction of embankment between Medawara and Akaba has already commenced, and a considerable amount of material for the construction of bridges has been sent down.

Medawara, which lies about 120 kilometres S.S.E. of Ma’an, is an excellent base for the construction of a branch line. It is well sup plied with water, cultivation flourishes, and provisions can be obtained on the spot The rolling stock of the line will shortly be largely increased, 10 large Kraus engines (all made in Germany) and about 150 carriage* and trucks having been ordered. The first lot of engines will arrive very shortly, at d sir greatly needed as the rolling stock on the main line from Damascus to Medawara has suffered greatly from inexperienced engineers, and in most cases requires a thorough repair and overhaul. The Bedouins have given heauthorities very little trouble lately having been timorised into peaceful ways by the Turk and Circassian mounted guards and no opposition is to be apprehended on the line between Akaba and Medawara.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL Restaurant.
div.p: Table d’Hote Luncheons & Dinners Served on the Terrace.
ORCHESTRA PLAYS 6 TO 11.30 P.M
DELIGHTFUL SITUATION - SEA BREEZES.

div.head: THE CAIRO SALON
div.p: CORRESPONDENT'S CRITICISM
DEARTH OF LOCAL CANVASES
A Cairo correspondent writes to ns as
follows :—

Those who visit the “Cercle Artistique” expecting to find, as in previous years, a collec­tion of charming views of Egypt and the East, by artists all more or less connected with the country, are likely to experience some disappointment. The present exhibition, which figures under the name of “L’Exposition des Beanx Arts,” is composed almost entirely of a series of pictures which, after having been displayed in the studios and galleries of Paris, have journeyed to Egypt in search of public favour. Amongst them are several of undoubt­ed merit, and these will be found well worthy of a visit. It is equally true, however, that the collection includes a great many which do not rise beyond the level of mediocrity.

But apart from the questions of merit or demerit, what strikes the Cairene is the sweeping change made in the nature of the exhibition by the elimination from it of what constituted the principal charm of previous shows, namely, their essentially local character. It may well be doubted whether this new departure will ’ render the exhibition more attractive either 1 to residents or strangers. The former class are naturally more interested in representations of Egyptian life and scenery, than in views of foreign countries, whilst the latter class will 1 hardly be attracted by works which they have already had opportunities of seeing in Europe, and which include such well worn subjects as l the Arc de Triomphe, Notre Dame, and the Parisian boulevards.

It is true that in one room of the building some of what may be called local pictures are displayed. But they are insignificant in number, end the room is so badly lighted that it is difficult to form an opinion as to their merits. So little have they been considered by the promoters of the exhibition that by f*r the greater n amber have not been even mentioned in the catalogue. Here also one looks in vain for the names of Talbot Kelly, John Varley, alfred East. Sir John Rogers, Binder Scarselli, and others, whose works formed such an attractive feature in previous exhibitions, and whose absence from the present one everyone interested in art in Egypt must deplore.

div.head: SAVOY CONCERT
div.p: Fraulein Nelly Schlar-Brodmann and Herr Buff Gressen gave a very interesting concert on Sunday night at the Savoy Hotel, which was well attended and obviously more than satisfied the audience. The acoustics of the concert- room militated against the complete success of either artist; both would have been heard to better advantage in an opera-house, espe­cially Herr Buff Gressen, whose powerful and very pure tenor organ did not quite accom­modate itself to the conditions. None the less he sang admirably, his rendering of the frail romance “In fernem Lande,” from Partial, and of Lohengrin's “Alschied,” the latter given as an encore, being extremely thorough and artistic, and after a course if Mediterranean misreadings of Wagner it was delightful to hear a German do full justice to music that can never perhaps be fully appreciated south of the Alps and the Loire. Fraulein Brodmann sang well throughout but for one noticeable mistake over a drop 'hat should have been clean but she slurred over three notes. She was at her best in the three Schumann songs, and gave a good rendering of Tosti’s Ninon, but her voice suffered from the room. In a concert- ball or opera-house it would have been far more attractive, but one can hardly criticise a performer who has not had time to learn the acoustics of the Savoy ball-room.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S SMALL DANCE
div.p: There was a numerous assembly on Monday night at Shepheard’s, when one of the usual small dances was in progress, and though there was perhaps a smaller proportion of residents and those living in other hotels present than in the commencement of the season, there was no diminution in the numbers of those who joined in the dance or amused themselves in less active fashion in the comfortable hall- passage. Nearly every one in the hotel must have been present, with the exception of the tired and travel-stained wayfarers from the further East, who filed through the brightly dressed crowd on their way to their rooms during the evening. The parquet floor if the Egyptian hall was in perfect condition and attracted several who thought their dancing days were over, and there were many who refused to tear themselves away from the festive scene till tin orchestra had resolutely refused to play a last encore. The programmes of the popular belles are now so crowded that their admirers have to console themselves with what are called “out dances,” and the extra waltzes given as encores are also eagerly sought after. It is to be feared that the hum-drum ances of England with their scarcity of men will no long-r he welcomed by those who n>n ^e danger of having their heads turned by ’ e glories of the Cairo season.

div.head: HEIR TO TURKISH THRONE
div.p: It is currently stated in Constantinople that Mohamed Rechad Effendi, her to the throne under the Ottoman law of succession, has bad serious apoplectic seizure. The news create o surprise because though not exactly f advanced years Rechad is in his 62nd year should he die his claims would descend to Yusuf Izzecin Effendi, who is 48 years of age. He is a Field Marshal of the Turkish Army and commands the Imperial guard.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Grand Duke Joseph of Austria is expect­ed to arrive at Alexandria on Monday next by the North German Lloyd steamer. The Khedive has placed a special train at his disposal.
H. E. the Governor of Alexandria left yester­day for Cairo.
Our Ghirgeh Correspondent telegraphs that Sir Horace Pinching arrived there to day.

Major P. W. Hardy, R.AM.C., Sanitary Officer in Egypt, came down to Alexandria from Cairo to-day on inspection duty. He leaves for Crete on the transport Dunera on the 24th inst, and returns by the same vessel.
Captain R L Mean, A.8.C., has come to Alexandria to await embarkation for England on the transport Dunera on the 1st proxo.

Sir Savile Brinton Crossley and Lady Cross- ley are staying at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel. Sir Savile Crossley represented Halifax in the House of Commons daring the last Parliament and on the formation of Mr. Balfour’s late Ministry in 1902 he was appointed Postmaster General and in the same year Privy Councillor. He succeeded his father, the first Baronet, in 1872. He served in the South African war as captain of the Imperial Yeomanry, when he received the medal with four deeps and was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, and he is Major and Hon. Lieut-Col of the Prince of Wales’ Own Norfolk Artillery Lady Crossley was the Hon. Phyllis de Bathe, daughter of Sir Henry de Bathe, who dis­tinguished himself in the Crimean War.

The following passengers left for Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Saturday : Mr. Cox and party of 2. Mr. and Mrs. C. Stephen, Dr. Love, Dr. Beddoe Mr. Singer. M. and Mme. Marquis de Angeres, Mr. Sinnot Hanna, Bimbachi Blerowe, Miralai Blunt, Mr. Alex­andria, Mr. Rosental, Mr. Philippe, Capt. Malin, Mr. Goussard, Mr. Waste, Birch Pacha, Mr. Webb.

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR
div.p: CABINET DISSENSIONS
HEAVY DEPRECIATION OF SHARES
London, February 20.
It is believed that considerable differences exist in the Cabinet concerning the Transvaal Constitution and the Chinese labour questions. (Reuter)
London, February 20

The heavy fall continues in Kaffirs on the Government’s policy. Difficulties are apprehend ed for the Thursday settlement. Since the 22nd of January, 40 leading shares have depre­ciated to the extent of £18,000,000. (Reuter)

div.head: GOVERNMENT POLICY
div.p: STATEMENT BY THE PREMIER
London, February 20.

House or Commons.—Sir H. Campbell-Ban­nerman said that so far as he knew the Algeciras Conference was proceeding slowly but satisfactorily. We were giving France our utmost diplomatic support without the slightest prejudice to our amity with other Powers. He emphatically declared that the understanding with France was as strongly entrenched as ever. He defended the giving immediately of a responsible Government to the Transvaal. The Government’s great aim in flaming a constitu­tion would be to avoid any appearance of unfairness.
He reiterated the accusation that the condi­tion of Chinese labour was servile and cruel. No Chinaman desirous of returning home would be kept back against his will. (Reuter)

div.head: THE ADRESS
div.p: ADOPTED BY THE LORDS
London, February 20.
The Lords adopted the Address. Lord Crew denied that the election was won by misrepre­sentations with regard to the importation of Chinese labour. (Reuter)

div.head: LIBERAL CANDIDATE FOR CITY
div.p: London, February 20
The City Liberals have selected Mr. Gibson Bowles to oppose Mr. Balfour in the City. (R.)

div.head: EXPEDITION TO SOKATO
div.p: A NEW MAHDI
Lagos, February 20

An expedition is going to Sokato, where fanatics have killed a company of mounted , troops, constituting practically half the garri­son, including 5 white officers, and captured a « Maxim gun. It is Relieved that they ware sur­prised by the followers of a new Mahdi who were well armed. The affair was utterly unexpected. (Reuter)

div.head: THE GARTHER MISSION
div.p: AN UNPARALLED HONOUR
Tokio, February 20
The Mikado did Prince Arthur of Connaught unparalleled honour in meeting his Royal Highness at the station amid enthusiastic ovations on the part of the populace (Reuter)

div.head: ANTI-FORGEIGN AGITATION IN CHINA
div.p: Tokio, February 20
Japan has called the attention of China to the advisability of checking any anti-foreign agitation. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMANY AND ABYSSINIA
div.p: COMMERCIAL TREATY
Berlin, February 20.
The Reichstag has passed the commercial treaty with Abyssinia. (Reuter)

div.head: THE HUNGARIAN DIET
div.p: SURROUNDED BY TROOPS
Buda Pest, February 20.

The Diet to-day was surrounded by troops. The Royal Commissioner sent in a rescript dis­solving the House and reserving the question of summoning another Diet. The Lower House unanimously returned the rescript unopened and adjourned. The Commissioner’s delegate subsequently read the rescript to an empty house. Troops cleared out the House and the officials sealed the doors. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH ELECTIONS
div.p: Paris, February 20.
The Legislative elections will take place on April 89. (Havas)

div.head: THE ELGECIRAS CONFERENCE
div.p: FAILURE INEVITABLE
Paris, February 20.
The opinion prevails here that the failure of the Conference of Algeciras is inevitable, the French and German views on the crucial ques­tion of the police being irreconcilable. (Reuter)
Paris, February 20
The newspapers are unanimous in stating that it is impossible to make any farther con­cessions in connection with Morocco. (Havas)

div.head: THE ORAN AFFAIR
div.p: Paris, February 20.
The Turki again bombarded the factory of Marchica and destroyed several sheds. (R.)

div.head: NEW FRENCH PRESIDENT
div.p: Paris, February 20.

M. Fallieres, in a message to the Chambers, emphasised the stability of the present regime and appealed for the co operation of all Repub­licans. He said that it was the sacred duty of the army to defend their country and the flag without menacing anybody. (Reuter)
Paris, February 20.
M. Fallieres’s message appeals for the co­operation of all Republicans and extols the defence of the country. (Havas)

15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.
